posts.name: AryanPatel
posts.cooked: Hi there! II’m just curious, did most teams CAD their own elevator or did they just model one after an andymark or WCP product. Some of these elevators look complex to CAD so I was wondering. If so, what are some good resources to get started?

posts.name: Karl Olson
posts.cooked: https://www.frcdesign.org/ offers a good starting point for learning to CAD FRC robots.

posts.name: Pizzatc
posts.cooked:
We CADed our own based off some other teams models but in order to get started I would use FRC Design Learning Course | FRCDesign.org

olsonkarlp beat me by 5s

posts.name: Isaac Proctor
posts.cooked: This year, we bought a WCP 2 Stage GreyT Cascade Elevator, and we copied WCPs CAD from their website and went into the part studios and such and adjusted all the lengths and such to make it the right size for our robot, and then created a separate assembly to add brackets and stuff using a part studio in context. We based the measurements off our master sketch, and had it inserted into our full assembly like everything else. It was very time consuming to get the CAD working, but it seemed to work pretty well in the end, and we didn’t really encounter any issues we couldn’t fix. This was our first year really doing parametric CAD, so i don’t know if that is the best way to do it, but it worked ok for us.

posts.name: Calvin Selin
posts.cooked: Our elevator cad was a nightmare.  I would Highly, Highly recommend cading your own.

posts.name: Kade Rabe
posts.cooked: generally you CAD it yourself, you could def base it heavily off the existing CAD they provide tho. this also gives you more flexibility to adjust or do certain things differently

posts.name: Camren
posts.cooked:
We found a configurable CAD model in OnShape that used the SDS elevator blocks. This will be the last time I put in a large configurable assembly into my CAD.

It was a major pain to make any modifications to it because the feature tree was almost impossible to navigate, and we almost cut the wrong size pieces because at one point the configuration got reverted to default.

I think 4 hours of work to CAD it up statically at the start would have saved us 20 hours of fussing around with the configured version throughout the season.

posts.name: James Lyon
posts.cooked: I disagree. I think large configurable assemblies are great, especially when it’s something like an elevator, as it allows teams to quickly add complex mechanisms to their CAD.  If the assemblies are setup improperly then yes, I can be a pain to work with. from what you’re saying it sounds like whoever made the assembly created multiple parts that don’t refence each other in the same part studio, which adds tons of unneeded complexity. As for the configurations reverting to default, Onshape has a weird quirk where every time you insert something into an assembly you have to set the configurations, otherwise it goes to default values.  I’m assuming that’s what happed it your case. I wouldn’t be so quick to never use Large configurable assemblies again; they can be a big help.

posts.name: Camren
posts.cooked:
I think that is a valid take, the way you are describing it is essentially a more complex krayonCAD.

Following through on your point further, i think teams could dedicate entire offseasons to building up repositories of configurable sub assemblies of parts they know they have on the shelf. This would give teams an advanced version of KrayonCAD to start their seasons

However I think this would only work if the models were built correctly and you had a principal mentor in place to ensure continuity through student turnover.

posts.name: James Lyon
posts.cooked:
Camren:

essentially a more complex krayonCAD.

Thats a good way to put it. The advantage is it can actually be used for a finalized CAD.

posts.name: Nick Aarestad
posts.cooked:
We used a combination of COTS parts and custom elements to design our 2025 elevator.

Similar to other posters, I’ve found fully configurable elevator assemblies to be somewhat problematic. Because of this, we did a mix of configurable and non-configurable parts for our 2025 robot.

Some of the configurable components can be found here:

Sign in to Onshape, the #1 fastest growing CAD system in the world with over 4 million users.

and then the elevator CAD can be found here:

Sign in to Onshape, the #1 fastest growing CAD system in the world with over 4 million users.

In terms of the complexity of CAD, I think it’s totally reasonable to look at an elevator as someone new to CAD and see it as extremely complex! Like most complex things, a reasonable way to approach the problem is to break it down into parts. You can see how we broke it down in the above documents-- one of the key reusable elements of CAD in an elevator is the end/stop assembly. These do not need to be physically connected as they are in our CAD but it often makes sense to constrain them together, since the assembly can be the same for all the parts of the elevator that use it.

On a rope elevator, that also helps make sure all your pulleys are in plane with each other, which reduces weird rope issues (if you’re using a rope elevator). If you poke around those documents a bit more, you’ll see some other configurable and non-configurable parts.

Ultimately, I think elevators are one of those things where you just have to go for it. Looking at existing custom or COTS elevator assemblies can be very helpful and informative, but often you want something just a little bit different, and having thought through how you need to do that (both for your team’s specific situation, and in general) is helpful in being able to execute quickly in-season.

Good luck!

posts.name: Calvin Selin
posts.cooked: I think frcdesign.org has some of the best CAD practices.

posts.name: Calvin Selin
posts.cooked: The thing with large configurable assemblies is that they’re hard to make parametric and integrate with the rest of the CAD.
